t1:
Article 5
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act;provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.
t2: A minor can freely dispose of assets the statutory agent permits the disposition without specifying the purpose.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a minor dispose of assets that the legal representative has permitted without specifying a purpose?

Rule: According to Article 5(3) of the law, a minor can freely dispose of assets that the legal representative has permitted them to dispose of, without specifying a purpose.

Application: If the legal representative permits a minor to dispose of certain assets without specifying a purpose, then the minor can dispose of those assets freely.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. A minor can dispose of assets that the legal representative has permitted them to dispose of without specifying a purpose.

t1:
Article 98-2
Any person may not assert a manifestation of intention against the other party thereto if that other party had no mental capacity or was a minor or an adult ward at the time of receiving it;provided, however, that this does not apply after either of the following persons learns of the manifestation of intention:
(i) the legal representative of the other party; or
(ii) the other party, after that other party's mental capacity has been restored or after that other party has become a person with capacity to act.
t2: If the other party of a manifestation of intention was a minor when the manifestation of intention was received, that manifestation of intention does not take effect.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Does a manifestation of intention take effect if the other party was a minor when it was received?

Rule: According to Article 98-2, any person cannot assert a manifestation of intention against the other party if that other party was a minor at the time of receiving it, except when the legal representative of the minor or the minor themselves, after their mental capacity has been restored or after they have become capable of acting, learn of the manifestation of intention.

Application: If the other party was a minor when they received the manifestation of intention, the manifestation of intention does not take effect unless the minor or their legal representative learns of it after their mental capacity has been restored or they have become capable of acting.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. If the other party was a minor when they received the manifestation of intention, the manifestation of intention does not take effect, except when the minor or their legal representative learns of it after their mental capacity has been restored or they have become capable of acting.

t1:
Article 96
(1) A manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.
(2) If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact.
(3) The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.
t2: In cases where a person who has consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person rescind their consent to the sale of real property if their consent was obtained through duress by a third party, and the other party was unaware of the duress?

Rule: According to Article 96(1), a manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable. However, according to Article 96(2), if a third party commits fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact. Additionally, under Article 96(3), the rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud or duress cannot be asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.

Application: If a person's consent to the sale of real property was obtained through duress by a third party, and the other party was unaware of the duress, the person cannot rescind their consent because the other party acted in good faith without negligence and did not know or could not have known about the duress.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. In cases where a person who has consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent. This is because the other party acted in good faith without negligence, and the rescission of the consent cannot be asserted against them.

t2: Even when a person, who carries a purchase-money obligation due to the sale of real property, while a minor pays the purchase money after becoming an adult, the person can rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person rescind a sale of real property if they were a minor at the time of the sale, but paid the purchase money after becoming an adult?

Rule: According to Article 125, a voidable act can be deemed ratified if certain events occur, such as full or partial performance, request for performance, novation, provision of security, assignment of a right acquired by the voidable act, or compulsory execution. However, this does not apply if an objection is reserved.

Application: If a person was a minor at the time of the sale of real property and carried a purchase-money obligation, but paid the purchase money after becoming an adult, the sale of the property is a voidable act. However, if any of the events listed in Article 125 occur, the act can be deemed ratified, and the person cannot rescind the sale. 

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. If a person was a minor at the time of the sale of real property and carried a purchase-money obligation, but paid the purchase money after becoming an adult, the sale of the property is a voidable act. However, if any of the events listed in Article 125 occur, the act can be deemed ratified, and the person cannot rescind the sale. Therefore, paying the purchase money after becoming an adult does not give the person the right to rescind the sale due to being a minor at the time of the sale.

t1:
Article 20
(1) After a person with qualified legal capacity who is involved in dealings with another party becomes a person with the legal capacity to act (meaning a person whose legal capacity to act is not subject to restrictions; the same applies hereinafter), the other party to those dealings may fix a period of one month or longer and demand that the person give a definite answer within that period of time as to whether the person will ratify an act that the person may rescind. In such a case, if the person fails to send a definite answer within that period of time, the person is deemed to have ratified that act.
(2) The second sentence of the preceding paragraph also applies if, before the person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party to dealings involving the person with qualified legal capacity lodges the demand prescribed in the preceding paragraph with the legal representative, curator, or assistant of that person with respect to an act within the scope of their authority, and they fail to send a definite answer within the fixed period of time referred to in that paragraph.
(3) If a person does not send notice within the period of time set forth in the preceding two paragraphs indicating that the person has completed any special formalities that an act requires, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
(4) The other party to dealings involving a person with qualified legal capacity may lodge a demand with a person under curatorship or with a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1) to demand that the person get the curator or assistant to ratify an act within the fixed period referred to in paragraph (1). In such a case, if the person under curatorship or person under assistance does not send notice within that period indicating that the person has gotten the curator or assistant to ratify the act in question, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
t2: For a contract executed by a person under curatorship, although the other party issue a notice to the person under curatorship which demands, by establishing a certain period which is one month or more, that he/she should obtain the ratification of his/her curator , the person under curatorship fails to issue, within the applicable period, from that point on, that other party cannot rescind the contract for the reason that the contract was executed by the person under curatorship.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a contract executed by a person under curatorship be rescinded if the other party demands that the person obtain the ratification of their curator but the person fails to do so within the applicable period?

Rule: According to Article 20(4), the other party to dealings involving a person under curatorship may demand that the person obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period. If the person under curatorship fails to provide notice within that period indicating that they have obtained the ratification of their curator, the act is deemed rescinded.

Application: If the other party demands that a person under curatorship obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period, but the person under curatorship fails to provide notice indicating that they have obtained the ratification of their curator, the act is deemed rescinded. Therefore, the other party cannot rescind the contract for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. If the other party demands that a person under curatorship obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period, but the person under curatorship fails to provide notice indicating that they have obtained the ratification of their curator, the act is deemed rescinded. Therefore, the other party cannot rescind the contract for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

t1:
Article 556
(1) An option contract for a purchase and sale made by one party becomes effective when the other party manifests the intention to complete the purchase and sale.
(2) If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention referred to in the preceding paragraph, the party to the option contact may issue a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to the effect that the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not that party will complete the sale within that period. In such cases, if the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period, the option contract for a purchase and sale by one party ceases to be effective.
t2: If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for a completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, regardless of whether or not the party to the pre contract issued a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period, for the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not he or she would complete the sale, if no definite answer has been given, the party to the pre contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a party demand execution of a contract of sale if no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no definite answer has been given by the other party?

Rule: According to Article 556(2), if no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and the party to the option contract issues a notice of demand to the other party specifying a reasonable period of time for a definite answer, but the other party fails to provide a definite answer within that period, the option contract for a purchase and sale by one party ceases to be effective.

Application: If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no definite answer has been given by the other party, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party. This is because the party to the option contract did not issue a notice of demand specifying a reasonable period of time for a definite answer, as required by Article 556(2).

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no definite answer has been given by the other party, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party. This is because the party to the option contract did not issue a notice of demand specifying a reasonable period of time for a definite answer, as required by Article 556(2).

t1:
Article 114
In the case referred to in the preceding Article, the counterparty may demand, by specifying a reasonable period of time, that the principal give a definite answer on whether or not the principal will ratify within that period of time.In this case, if the principal fails to give a definite answer within that period, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify.
t2: For a contract completed by an unauthorized agent, regardless of the fact that the counterparty requires the principal, by fixing a reasonable period of time, to make a definite answer on whether or not he/she will ratify within such period of time , if no definite answer has been given, the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a contract completed by an unauthorized agent be demanded for execution by the principal if the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify within a reasonable period of time, but no definite answer has been given?

Rule: According to Article 114, if a contract has been completed by an unauthorized agent, the counterparty may demand that the principal give a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify within a reasonable period of time. If the principal fails to give a definite answer within that period, they are deemed to have refused to ratify.

Application: If a contract has been completed by an unauthorized agent and the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify within a reasonable period of time, but no definite answer has been given, the other party cannot demand execution of the contract to the principal. This is because the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify the contract by not providing a definite answer within the specified period of time.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. If a contract has been completed by an unauthorized agent and the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify within a reasonable period of time, but no definite answer has been given, the other party cannot demand execution of the contract to the principal. This is because the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify the contract by not providing a definite answer within the specified period of time.

t1:
Article 506
(1) Set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other. In such a case, no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention.
(2) A manifestation of intention as referred to in the preceding paragraph is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.
t2: A time limit can be added to the manifestation of intention of offset, but conditions cannot be added.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a time limit be added to the manifestation of intention of offset?

Rule: According to Article 506(1), set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other, and no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention.

Application: The application of Article 506(1) is clear - no time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention of offset. Therefore, the hypothesis is false with respect to time limits.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 506(1), no time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention of offset. Conditions are also not allowed to be added to the manifestation of intention.

t1:
Article 137
The obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if:
(i) the obligor has become subject to the order commencing bankruptcy proceeding;
(ii) the obligor has lost, damaged, or diminished the security; or
(iii) the obligor fails to provide security when it has the obligation to do so.
t2: In cases where the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, if the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can an obligor assert the benefit of time stipulation if they fail to provide security when obligated to do so?

Rule: According to Article 137(iii), an obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if they fail to provide security when they have the obligation to do so.

Application: If an obligor of monetary debt has an obligation to provide security but fails to do so, they cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation. Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 137(iii), if an obligor of monetary debt has an obligation to provide security but fails to do so, they cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation.

t1:
Article 134
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
t2: A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on  the willof the obligor.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a juridical act subject to a condition precedent be void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor?

Rule: According to Article 134, a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.

Application: If a juridical act is subject to a condition precedent that is dependent solely on the intention of the obligor, then the act is void according to Article 134. Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 134, a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.

t1:
Article 233
(1) If a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch.
(2) If a tree or bamboo root from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the owner of the land may sever that root.
t2: When a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land cross a boundary line, the person can remove the branch him or herself, but cannot have the owner of that tree or bamboosever the branch.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person have the owner of a neighboring tree or bamboo sever a branch that crosses a boundary line?

Rule: According to Article 233(1), if a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch.

Application: If a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 233(1), if a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch. The person cannot remove the branch themselves unless they have permission from the owner of the tree or bamboo.

t1:
Article 243
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.
t2: If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Who has ownership of a composite thing made up of two or more movables with different owners that can no longer be separated without damage?

Rule: According to Article 243, if two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property.

Application: If two or more movables with different owners are so joined that they cannot be separated without damage, ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movables. Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 243, if two or more movables with different owners are so joined that they can no longer be separated without damaging them, ownership of the composite thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movable.

t1:
Article 244
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
t2: If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: How are owners of a composite thing determined if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between joined movables?

Rule: According to Article 244, if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.

Application: If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession. Therefore, the hypothesis is false. 

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 244, if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession. The owners are not determined by court, but rather ownership is determined based on the respective price of each movable at the time of the accession.

t1:
Article 292
If dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.
t2: Even if there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, due to factors of the other co-owners, such extinctive prescription proceeds.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Does the interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land affect the prescription period of the other co-owners?

Rule: According to Article 292, if dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.

Application: If there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, due to factors of the other co-owners, the prescription period is not affected for any of the co-owners. According to Article 292, the postponement or renewal of prescription period is effective for the benefit of all co-owners, so the interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner does not lead to the prescription period proceeding for the other co-owners.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false based on the legal reasoning approach. According to Article 292, the interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land does not affect the prescription period of the other co-owners. The postponement or renewal of prescription period is effective for the benefit of all co-owners.

Article 348
The pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, upon the pledgee's own responsibility.In this case, the pledgee is responsible for any loss arising from the subpledge even if the same is caused by force majeure.
t2: A pledgee can sub-pledge a Thing pledged without the approval of the owner of the Thing pledged.

False. The given hypothesis does not accurately reflect the rule and application stated in the premise.

Hypothesis: A pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, but the pledgee is responsible for any loss arising from the subpledge, even if caused by force majeure, and the approval of the owner of the thing pledged is not required.

Article 355
If more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follow the chronological order of their creation.
t2: Pledges on movable property do not take effect if there is no delivery, and thus, for that movable, multiple pledges cannot be created.
ChatGPT_output:
False. The given hypothesis does not accurately reflect the rule and application stated in the premise.

The correct hypothesis, following the legal reasoning approach, would be:

Hypothesis: The order of priority of pledges on movable property follows the chronological order of their creation, regardless of whether delivery has been made or not. Multiple pledges can be created on the same movable property, and their priority is determined by the order of creation.

t1:
Article 353
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
t2: If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Can a pledgee of movables recover the same if the pledged thing is usurped?
Rule: Article 353 of the Civil Code states that a pledgee of movables may recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.

Application: In the context of a pledge on movable property, if the possession of the pledgee is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can file an action for recovery of possession based on the pledge.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 400
If the subject matter of a claim is the delivery of a specific thing, the obligor must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager, which is determined in light of the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction, until the delivery.
t2: The obligor of a claim whose subject is the delivery of  any specified things carries the duty to preserve that thing until the delivery is performed with the same  care  he/she would exercise over his/her own property.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 400 of the Japanese Civil Code, if the subject matter of a claim is the delivery of a specific thing, the obligor (i.e., the person who owes the delivery) must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager, which is determined in light of the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction, until the delivery. Therefore, the obligor must exercise the same care over the specific thing as he/she would exercise over his/her own property.

t1:
Article 403
If the amount of the claim is designated in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor may make the payment in Japanese currency converted with the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance.
t2: Even if the amount of the claim was specified in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor can make the payment in the legal currency of Japan instead of currency of the foreign state.
ChatGPT_output:
False. The hypothesis is not true according to the given legal reasoning approach. 

According to Article 403, if the amount of the claim is designated in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor may make the payment in Japanese currency converted with the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance. This means that the obligor can make the payment in Japanese currency, but the amount of the payment should be equivalent to the amount designated in the foreign currency at the exchange rate at the place of the performance. Therefore, the obligor cannot make the payment in the legal currency of Japan instead of the currency of the foreign state if the claim is designated in the foreign currency.

t1:
Article 406
If the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice being made from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.
t2: If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision.
ChatGPT_output: True. The hypothesis accurately reflects the rule stated in Article 406 of the Civil Code of Japan. According to the article, if the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor. This means that the obligor has the power to select which performance will satisfy the obligation, as long as there is no agreement or provision to the contrary.

t1:
Article 410
If a performance included in the subject matter of a claim is impossible, and the impossibility is by negligence of the party that has the right to choose, the claim exists to the extent of the remaining performances.
t2: If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among two performances, if one of the performances becomes impossible in the future not due to fault of persons involved that do not possess the right to choose, then the subject of the claim is identified  as the other performance.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to Article 410, if a performance included in the subject matter of a claim is impossible due to negligence of the party that has the right to choose, the claim exists to the extent of the remaining performances. However, if one of the performances becomes impossible in the future not due to fault of persons involved that do not possess the right to choose, the party with the right to choose must choose the remaining performance, if possible, or the claim may become partially or fully impossible to perform.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
t2: If the mandatary suffer any loss due to the administration of the mandated business s without negligence in the mandatary, he/she can claimcompensation for the loss from the mandator.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 650(3), if a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to their negligence in order to administer the mandated business, they may claim compensation for this from the mandator.

t1:
Article 465-2
(1) A guarantor to a guarantee contract under which the principal obligation is one or more unidentified obligations within a certain specified scope (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee") and the guarantor is not a corporation (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee by an individual") is liable to perform the obligation in terms of the amounts of the principal of the principal obligation, any interest, penalty and compensation for loss or damage in connection with the principal obligation, and all the other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as the amount of any penalty or compensation for loss or damage which is agreed- upon on with regard to the guarantee obligation, up to a certain maximum amount which pertains to all of these amounts.
(2) A contract for revolving guarantee by an individual does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount prescribed in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of Article 446, paragraphs (2) and (3) apply mutatis mutandis to the provisions concerning a maximum amount prescribed in paragraph (1) in a contract for revolving guarantee by an individual.
t2: In a revolving guarantee contract on loans, even if the principal determination date is determined, if the maximum amount is not stipulated, it shall not be effective.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is partially true. According to Article 465-2(2), a contract for revolving guarantee by an individual does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount prescribed in the preceding paragraph (which refers to the maximum amount pertaining to all amounts of the principal obligation, any interest, penalty, compensation for loss or damage, and other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as any penalty or compensation for loss or damage agreed upon in relation to the guarantee obligation). However, the premise of the hypothesis only mentions the determination of the principal and does not directly relate to the requirement for a maximum amount.

t1:
Article 612
(1) A lessee may not assign the lease or sublease a leased thing without obtaining the approval of the lessor.
(2) If the lessee allows any third party to make use of or take the profits of a leased thing in violation of the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the lessor may cancel the contract.

Article 467
(1) The assignment of a claim (including the assignment of a claim that is yet to arise) may not be duly asserted against the applicable obligor or any other third party, unless the assignor gives notice thereof to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same.
(2) Notice or consent as referred to in the preceding paragraph may not be duly asserted against a third party other than the obligor unless the notice or the consent is made using an instrument bearing a certified date.

ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is False.

According to the rule in Article 467(1), an assignment of a claim may not be duly asserted against the applicable obligor or any other third party unless the assignor gives notice to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same. Therefore, for the obligor to refuse to execute the assignment of the claim, the assignor must give notice of the assignment or obtain the obligor's consent. 

If the assignee demands the obligor to execute the assignment, the obligor has the right to refuse unless he/she has been notified or has given consent. The burden of proof lies on the assignee to demonstrate that the notice was given or consent was obtained.

t1:
Article 493
The tender of the performance must be made actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation;provided, however, that if the obligee refuses to accept that performance in advance or if any act is required on the part of the obligee with respect to the performance of the obligation, it is sufficient for the obligor to request the acceptance thereof by giving a notice that the tender of the performance has been prepared.

ChatGPT_output:
False.

According to Article 493, the tender of performance must be made actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation. This means that the performance must be made in a manner that is consistent with the requirements of the obligation, and not just in any manner the obligor chooses. 

In the case of a monetary debt, if the obligor brings cash to the address of the obligee and demands acceptance, but the obligee refuses to accept, this would not be considered a valid tender of performance. The obligor would need to make the payment in a manner that is consistent with the requirements of the obligation, which may include delivering the cash directly to the obligee or making a bank transfer, for example.

t1:
Article 492
Upon tendering the performance, the obligor is relieved from any and all responsibilities which may arise from the non-performance of the obligation.
t2: In cases where the obligor of a monetary debt provides actual performance on the time of performance, but the obligee refuses to accept the performance, the obligor does not carry the duty to pay delinquent charges after the provision.
ChatGPT_output:
False. 

While the obligor is generally relieved of their responsibility upon tendering the performance, in cases where the obligee refuses to accept the performance, the obligor may still be responsible for any damages or losses that result from the non-acceptance of the performance. Additionally, the obligation to pay any delinquent charges or interest may continue to accrue until the obligee accepts the performance. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

Article 551
(1) The donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift.
(2) With respect to gifts with burden, the donor provides the same warranty as that of a seller, to the extent of that burden.
t2: In cases where a gift of the specified thing is made without the donee bearing the responsibility, if the donor made the gift without knowing that the subject matter has a defect, the donor shall not assume a warranty for the defect.
ChatGPT_output:
Conclusion: False

Reasoning: 

According to the given premise, in cases where a gift is made, the donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift. Therefore, the donor is expected to assume a warranty for any defect that existed at the time of the gift. 

In other words, the donor is responsible for defects that existed at the time of the gift, regardless of whether the donor knew about them or not. Therefore, the hypothesis that the donor shall not assume a warranty for the defect if the donor made the gift without knowing that the subject matter has a defect is false.

t1:
Article 562
(1) If the subject matter delivered to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract with respect to the kind, quality or quantity, the buyer may demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance by repairing the subject matter, delivering the substitute or delivering the replenishment;provided, however, that the seller may cure the non-conformity of performance by a method that is different from the method demanded by the buyer if it does not impose any undue burden on the buyer.
(2) If the non-conformity referred to in the preceding paragraph is due to grounds attributable to the buyer, the buyer may not demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance under the provisions of that paragraph.
Article 533
A party to a bilateral contract may refuse to perform that party's own obligation until the other party tenders the performance of that other party's obligation (including the performance of an obligation to compensate for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of an obligation);provided, however, that this does not apply if the obligation of the other party is not yet due.

ChatGPT_output:
False. The two premises presented do not directly support the hypothesis.

Article 562 provides rules on non-conformity of performance in sales contracts. It allows the buyer to demand that the seller cure the non-conformity, but does not mention anything about the buyer being able to refuse payment.

Article 533 allows a party to refuse to perform their own obligation until the other party performs their obligation, but it does not specifically address defects in work performed or the right to refuse payment.

Therefore, there is no clear support for the hypothesis presented.

Article 648

(3) In the following cases, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed:

(ii) if the mandate is terminated during the course of performance.

ChatGPT_output: False. According to Article 648(3)(ii), if the mandate is terminated during the course of performance, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed. Therefore, if the mandatary cancels the contract of mandate in the middle of performance of the mandated business, they can demand payment of remuneration for the work already completed.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.

Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 632
A contract for work become effective when one of the parties promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work.
Article 633
Remuneration must be paid simultaneously with delivery of the subject matter of work performed;provided, however, that if no delivery of a thing is required, the provisions of Article 624, paragraph (1) apply mutatis mutandis.
t2: In a lawsuit demanding the payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract for work has been concluded and, if the delivery of the subject matter of work is required, that this has been delivered.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Whether proof of contract and delivery of the subject matter is required in a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work. 

Rule: According to Article 632, a contract for work becomes effective when one party promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration. And Article 633 states that remuneration must be paid simultaneously with the delivery of the subject matter of work performed, except if no delivery of a thing is required. 

Application: Therefore, in a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract for work has been concluded, and if the delivery of the subject matter of work is required, that it has been delivered. 

Conclusion: Hence, the hypothesis that proof of contract and delivery of the subject matter is required in a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work is true according to the legal reasoning approach.

t1:
Article 704
A beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this.
t2: The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: What is the liability of a beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment?
Rule: Article 704 provides that a beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same.
Application: If a person receives a benefit from another person in bad faith, knowing that they have no right to receive it, they are considered a beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment. In such a case, the beneficiary must return the benefit received and pay interest on it. If any damages still remain, the beneficiary is also liable to compensate for them.
Conclusion: The hypothesis is true - the beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same.

Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

However, if the obligor tendered anything by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result. Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 707
(1) If a person that is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake and the obligee, acting in good faith, has allowed the instrument to be lost, has damaged the instrument, has waived the security, or has lost the claim by prescription, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of subject matter of the performance.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the person performing an obligation from exercising the right to reimbursement against the obligor.
t2: Performance by a third party is also effective, and thus even if the an obligation of another person has been performed by mistake, the person who made the performance cannot demand the return of the performance to the obligee.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is true. According to Article 707, if a person who is not an obligor mistakenly performs an obligation and the obligee, acting in good faith, has taken certain actions such as allowing the instrument to be lost or losing the claim by prescription, the person who performed the obligation may not demand the return of the subject matter of the performance. This means that the performance by a third party is considered valid, and even if it was done by mistake, the person who made the performance cannot demand its return from the obligee. However, the person performing the obligation can exercise the right to reimbursement against the obligor.
